flares.note: Associated with full halo CME observed in GOES CCOR-1 and rise in GOES >10 MeV protons.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east/northeast in STEREO A COR2 imagery only. The source may be related to a minor eruption near Active Region 14274 (N27E31) which deflects northward starting around 2025-11-07T02:30Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 and STEREO A EUVI 195/304 imagery. However, this source is speculative. As this CME is not observed in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 or GOES CCOR-1 imagery it is difficult to confirm the source.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 41 degrees with STEREO A COR2 imagery as the source location is speculative and this event is not observed in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 or GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. While the bulk of this event is directed towards the northeast, a faint halo feature is produced from the shock of this CME. The source is an M1.7 flare from Active Region 14274 (N27E27) starting around 2025-11-07T07:00Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 284, 304 imagery. Dimming is observed north of the eruption site in GOES SUVI 195 imagery, with minor field line movement visible over the northeast limb in GOES SUVI 195/284 imagery. This eruption can be observed near the northeast limb in STEREO A EUVI 195/304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the bright northeast bulk feature based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery.
SHOCK measurement of the fainter halo feature, which surrounds the brighter northeast bulk feature, based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the north in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to an eruption centered near N40E30, which appears to deflect to the northwest, starting around 2025-11-07T10:30Z as seen in GOES SUVI 304 and STEREO A EUVI imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to an eruption northeast of Active Region 14274 (N35E30) starting around 2025-11-07T12:00Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 imagery. An EUV wave is observed northeast of the eruption site as seen in GOES SUVI 195 imagery, with a wide opening of field lines observed over the northeast limb in GOES SUVI 195/284 imagery. Post eruptive arcades begin to form around 2025-11-07T14:00Z as seen in GOES SUVI 171/195 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: Narrow, jet-like CME first seen to the SW in COR2A only starting at 2025-11-07T23:08Z. This CME is much easier to distinguish in running difference imagery. There is no visible source of this CME on the Earth-facing disk or in STA EUVI imagery, so this source is very likely far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement from the perspective of STEREO A which is ~49 degrees west of Earth.

cmes.note: Halo CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-11-09T07:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 and in the NE by STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is an X1.7 flare from Active Region 14274 (N27E03) which peaked at 2025-11-09T07:35Z seen in GOES SUVI 131. Dimming and field line movement associated with this flare seen in GOES SUVI 171, 193 and 284 appears to have a Northwestern trajectory, suggesting the possibility of deflection. This CME has appears to have a very asymmetric morphology from the perspective of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. There does not appear to be a shock feature associated with this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Faint CME first seen to the South by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-11-09T12:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, and to the SE by STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This event is obscured by the pylon in GOES CCOR-1. The source of this event is a small filament eruption seen located at approx. S25E25 in GOES SUVI 304, with lift off beginning around 2025-11-09T12:20Z. Dimming seen in GOES SUVI 195 suggests a possible Southern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: Slow, wide, likely streamer blowout CME lacking defined front seen to the North by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-11-09T13:25Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The source of this event appears to be some continued field line movement and opening following X1.7 flare and eruption which peaked at 2025-11-09T07:35Z as seen in GOES SUVI 195 and 285.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the West in SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-11-09T13:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The source of this event is a slow rising prominence seen along the West limb in GOES SUVI 304 and on the Western disk in STEREO A EUVI 304 (approx. N00W100) starting as early as 2025-11-09T06:45Z. This CME is likely deflected due to proximity to a coronal hole.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: This CME is faint but visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery and to the southwest in STEREO A COR2 imagery for a few frames before becoming too diffuse to observe. The CME is not visible in GOES CCOR-1. The source is likely far-sided as there are no signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the south in STEREO A COR2, and to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. The source is a filament eruption observed near the southwest limb in GOES SUVI 304 imagery which begins to lift off around 2025-11-09T22:00Z. A subsequent opening of field lines can be observed over the southwest limb in GOES SUVI 284 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is seen starting slowly to the W/NW in STEREO A COR2, SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and GOES CCOR-1. The source is a filament eruption observed near or beyond the northwest limb in STEREO A EUVI 195/304 imagery starting around 2025-11-09T22:15Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C3 imagery. The CME initially measured less than 200 km/s but was reanalyzed with later frames and sped up significantly.

cmes.note: Narrow, relatively slow CME embedded within the core of slow CME first seen at 2025-11-10T00:48Z seen in the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2; the source is far-sided as evidenced by moving field lines seen around 2025-11-10T03:00Z in GOES SUVI 284 off the west limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2A.

cmes.note: Halo CME seen in SOHO LASCO C2, SOHO LASCO C3, and GOES CCOR-1 and wide CME seen predominantly to the northeast in STEREO A COR2A in association with an eruptive X1.2-class solar flare from Active Region 14274 (N25W16). The solar flare is best seen in GOES SUVI 131 and a faint circular EUV wave is seen propagating shortly following the flare in GOES SUVI 195 and 284 angstrom imagers.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the shock front out to 13 solar radii.
Updated bulk measurement out to 25 solar radii.
Preliminary measurement of the bulk with very few frames.

cmes.note: Seemingly narrow eruption to the N from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1's perspective, but appears wider and more to the N/NE in STEREO A COR2's field of view. From STEREO A's perspective, it drifts N as it moves out in the field of view. The source appears to be an eruption associated with filament ejecta visible to the N/NW from AR 14274 around 2025-11-10T12:00Z as seen in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit, however the feature continues to drift north in the STEREO A COR2 field of view and may have a more northern deflection in later frames not properly captured in this measurement.

cmes.note: Large halo CME first seen to the NE by STEREO A COR2 beginning at 2025-11-11T10:23Z, as well as to the NW by SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The source of this event is an X5.1 flare from Active Region 14274 (N27W27) which peaked at 2025-11-11T10:04Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131. Wide opening field lines and a large EUV wave and instance of dimming is visible in GOES SUVI 195 and 284 and STEREO A EUVI 195, along with post eruptive arcades visible in GOES SUVI 131 and 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.
SHOCK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: This CME/outflow is visible to the northwest in GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is difficult to observe in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to particle contamination from high proton fluxes following the 2025-11-11T09:45Z solar energetic particle event. The source is unknown as this event is likely outflow following CME: 2025-11-11T10:23Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees due to the unknown source location and difficulty in observing this event in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 or STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME/outflow is visible to the northwest in GOES CCOR-1 and to the northeast STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event is difficult to observe in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to particle contamination from high proton fluxes following the 2025-11-11T09:45Z solar energetic particle event. The source is unknown as this event is likely outflow following CME: 2025-11-11T10:23Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME/outflow is visible to the north in GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is difficult to observe in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to particle contamination from high proton fluxes following the 2025-11-11T09:45Z solar energetic particle event. The source is unknown as this event is likely outflow following CME: 2025-11-11T10:23Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees due to the uncertain source location and difficulty in observing this event in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery for a few frames before becoming too diffuse to observe. The source may be related to a minor eruption centered near N10W70 as seen in GOES SUVI 304 imagery starting around 2025-11-11T15:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the NNW in GOES CCOR-1 starting around 2025-11-12T17:45Z. This CME is also faintly seen to the N in STEREO A COR2 for a couple frames. This event is difficult to observe in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to particle contamination from high proton fluxes following the 2025-11-11T11:09Z solar energetic particle event detected at SOHO. The source is most likely a filament eruption beginning around 2025-11-12T16:00Z from near AR 14274 that appears to be deflected northward. The CME is also likely associated with a C4.5 flare from AR 14274 peaking at 2025-11-12T16:39Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best-fit measurement based on GOES CCOR-1 and limited imagery from STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: Extremely faint CME seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 but too faint in C3 and GOES CCOR-1. Its source may potentially be the minor eruption in AR 4274 (N24W51), directed northward and seen in GOES SUVI 304 at 2025-11-13T01:15Z, however the fit with two coronagraphs indicates that the CME is far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs indicates the source should be behind the NW limb, however no source has been found in STEREO A EUV imagery to confirm this fit. Because of the extreme faintness of the CME and the lack of coronal signatures these parameters are rather speculative.

cmes.note: CME seen to the W in SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1 and not seen at all in STEREO A coronagraph. The source of it could be a C6.1 flare from AR 4274 (N24W51) peaking after 2025-11-13T03Z, however no eruption/coronal signatures of the CME have been seen in EUV imagery associated with this flare though.

cmeAnalyses.note: This analysis was made with one coronagraph based on the location of C6.1 flare from Active Region 14274 as one potential source. However, there is no eruption seen in association with the flare. The CME is not seen in STEREO A coronagraph, so this analysis is rather speculative.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery for a few frames before becoming too diffuse to observe. The source is likely far-sided and may be related to a faint opening of field lines observed over the east/southeast limb in GOES SUVI 284 imagery starting around 2025-11-13T08:50Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is related to an eruption from Active Region 14247 (N30W58) which exhibits clear northern deflection as seen in GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 and STEREO A EUVI 195/304 imagery starting around 2025-11-13T14:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is a filament eruption spanning S30E50 to S25E05 which begins to lift off around 2025-11-13T17:30Z as seen in GOES SUVI 171/195/284/304 and STEREO A EUVI 195/304 imagery. Dimming is observed south of the eruption starting around 2025-11-13T18:30Z in GOES SUVI 195 imagery, and post eruptive arcades can be seen starting around 2025-11-13T19:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Noting that this event is partially obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event overlaps with preceding CME: 2025-11-13T18:38Z. The source may be related to an eruption centered near S20E55 starting around 2025-11-13T19:40Z seen best in GOES SUVI 304 imagery. However, it is also possible this event is associated with the southeast filament eruption which was associated with CME: 2025-11-13T18:38Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: Asymmetric halo seen with bulk to the northwest with a faint halo-shaped shock in SOHO LASCO C2/LASCO C3 with wider bulk seen to the north and northwest in STEREO A COR2A associated with an X4.0-class solar flare from AR14274 (N24W71). The eruption is characterized by brightening seen best in GOES SUVI 131 and as well in GOES SUVI 195 and GOES SUVI 284 imagery with a significant, rapid field line movement and darkening seen off the northwest limb around 2025-11-14T07:45Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the BULK using source location seen in available UV imagery and best fit between several frames of SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1.
Preliminary measurement of the bulk of the CME using limited SOHO LASCO C2/C3 frames and STEREO A COR2 out to 17 solar radii.
Measurement of the SHOCK feature using the best fit between several frames of SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2.
